{{Infobox comedian | name = John Oliver | image = John Oliver Occupy Wall Street 2011 Shankbone.JPG | imagesize = | caption = Oliver at [[Occupy Wall Street]], October 2011 | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|4|23}} | birth_place = [[Birmingham, England]], [[United Kingdom|UK]] | medium = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | active = 2001âpresent | genre = [[Political satire]] | subject = | influences = | influenced = | spouse = Kate Norley | notable_work = ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'', ''[[The Bugle]]'', ''[[Political Animal]]'', ''[[The Department]]'', ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'' | signature = | website = <!-- was mrjohnoliver.com, but has been stolen --> | footnotes = }}{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} '''John <!--Cornelius is Not his middle name!-->Oliver''' (born 23 April 1977) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[stand-up comedian]], actor, and writer. He is best known for his work on ''[[The Daily Show|The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', for which he won an [[Emmy]] in 2009. He also plays a recurring character, Professor Ian Duncan, on the television series ''[[Community (TV Series)|Community]]''. He has worked extensively with [[Andy Zaltzman]]; their body of work includes hundreds of hours of satirical podcasts and radio broadcasts, including series such as ''[[Political Animal (radio)|Political Animal]]'', ''[[The Department]]'', and ''[[The Bugle]]''. He is a [[Permanent residence (United States)|permanent resident]] of the [[United States]] and lives in [[New York City]].
==Early life== Oliver was born in [[Birmingham]], raised in [[Liverpool]] and [[Bedford]], and educated at [[Mark Rutherford School]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.markrutherford.beds.sch.uk/students_wherearethey.asp |title=Mark Rutherford Upper School & Community College |publisher=Markrutherford.beds.sch.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2007/jul/23/mondaymediasection.broadcasting4 |title=Interview with John Oliver â The Guardian |date=23 July 2007 |accessdate=21 April 2009 | location=London}} </ref> He is a graduate of [[Christ's College, Cambridge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/reporter/1997-8/weekly/5744/5.html |title=Reporter 8/7/98: Congregations of the Regent House on 26 and 27 June 1998 |publisher=Admin.cam.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> where he studied English and was Vice-President of the [[Footlights|Cambridge Footlights]] for 1997-98, when the President was British comedian, actor, writer, and director [[Richard Ayoade]]. He also featured in that year's revue, ''Between a Rock and a Hard Place''.<ref> {{cite news |title=Cambridge Footlights Alumni 1990â1999 |url=http://www.footlights.org/1990.html |accessdate=April 21, 2009}} </ref>
==Career== ===Stand-up=== Oliver first appeared at the [[Edinburgh Fringe|Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in [[2001 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2001]] as part of ''The Comedy Zone'', a late-night showcase of newer acts. He performed his debut solo show in [[2002 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2002]] and returned in [[2003 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2003]]. In [[2004 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2004]] and [[2005 Edinburgh Festival Fringe|2005]], he collaborated with [[Andy Zaltzman]] on a [[double act]] and co-hosting ''[[Political Animal (radio)|Political Animal]]'', with various acts performing political material.
After relocating to [[New York City]] for ''[[The Daily Show]]'', Oliver began performing stand-up in small clubs around the city, later moving on to headline shows in larger venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/comedy/2529/oliver-twisted |title=Oliver twisted â Time Out New York Issue 593 |date=February 8, 2007 |accessdate=April 21, 2009}} </ref>
Oliver's first [[stand-up]] specialâentitled ''John Oliver: Terrifying Times''âdebuted on [[Comedy Central]] on 20 April 2008 and was later released on [[DVD]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shop.comedycentral.com/detail.php?p=71408|title=John Oliver: Terrifying Times|publisher=comedycentral.com|accessdate=2009-03-27}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
===''The Daily Show with Jon Stewart''=== [[File:John Oliver Wyatt Cenac hug Shankbone.jpg|thumb|Oliver and [[Wyatt Cenac]] at the launch of ''[[Earth (The Book)]]''.]] John Oliver joined ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'' as its Senior British Correspondent in July 2006. "I've always striven to be both an entertainer and an irritant. I think that's why I feel so at home on ''The Daily Show''," quipped Oliver in a January 2009 interview.<ref name="Comic Crumpet"> {{cite web |url = http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/John+Oliver%3A+Comic+Crumpet/ |title = John Oliver: Comic Crumpet |publisher = [[SuicideGirls.com]] |date = 13 January 2009 |accessdate = 2009-01-14 }} </ref> Oliver won an [[Emmy]] in 2009 for "Best Comedy Writing In A Comedy or Variety Series" for his work on ''The Daily Show''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wellmonttheatre.com/event/4832|title=John Oliver - The Wellmont Theatre - Montclair - NJ - Oct 1, 2010|accessdate=6 December 2010}}</ref>
===''The Bugle''=== {{Main|The Bugle}} Since October 2007 Oliver has co-hosted ''[[The Bugle]]'', a weekly [[satirical]] comedy [[podcast]] for ''[[TimesOnline]]'', with [[Andy Zaltzman]]. The 100th episode aired in January 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/audio_video/podcasts/the_bugle/ |title=The Bugle â Audio Newspaper For A Visual World|publisher=timesonline.co.uk | location=London | accessdate=2010-05-07 | first1=Sam | last1=Coates | first2=Francis | last2=Elliott | first3=Roland | last3=Watson}}</ref>
===Other work=== Oliver wrote and presented the current [[BBC America]] campaign to have viewers use [[closed captioning]] ([[subtitles]]). Shown in brief segments before shows, "The following program contains accents you would have heard a lot more if you hadn't [[Boston Tea Party|thrown our tea into Boston Harbor]]," says one. "Not even British people can follow the British accent 100 percent of the time. Therefore you, like me, might want to use closed-captioning." Oliver has begun using some of these jokes in his current stand up routine.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.tvweek.com/blogs/blink/2007/05/translated_from_the_british.php| title=Translated from the British| date=2007-05-21| accessdate=2008-04-19| publisher=TVWeek}}</ref> [[File:Wyatt Cenac, John Oliver and Rory Albanese at Moravian College.jpg|thumb|right|225px|[[Wyatt Cenac]], John Oliver and [[Rory Albanese]] after performing stand-up comedy at [[Moravian College]] in [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania|Bethlehem]], [[Pennsylvania]] in April 2009]] John Oliver was a semi-regular panellist on the first two series of ''[[Mock the Week]]'' and frequently appeared on ''[[Fighting Talk]]''.
Oliver appeared briefly in the series ''[[Green Wing]]'' as a car salesman.
In 2008 Oliver was given his first [[motion picture]] role, playing Dick Pants in ''[[The Love Guru]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2007/09/05/5749/olivers_movie_break | title=Oliver's movie break | publisher=Chortle.co.uk | date=2007-09-05 | accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref>
Oliver performed various roles in the 2009 [[Comedy Central]] series ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]''.
Oliver appears in a recurring capacity on the [[NBC]] comedy ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' as Dr. Ian Duncan, a psychology professor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2009/05/nbc-new-fall-sh.html|title=Rating NBC's new fall shows: 'Parenthood,' a 'Trauma,' a 'Community,' '100 Questions,' and oh 'Mercy'!|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=2009-05-04|accessdate=2009-05-04}}</ref> However, he declined becoming a regular cast member of the series because he did not want to leave ''The Daily Show'' for it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/comedy/76544/interview-with-john-oliver-of-the-daily-show-and-community|title=Interview with John Oliver of "The Daily Show" and "Community"|publisher=Time Out New York|date=2009-07-23|accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref>
John Oliver, along with fellow ''The Daily Show'' writer [[Rory Albanese]], signed a blind script deal with [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/television/news/e3idb676dc68387c3add14f73cc4971cd74|title='Daily Show' duo in Paramount deal|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|date=2009-08-05|accessdate=2009-08-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
John Oliver hosts a stand-up series entitled ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'', which features himself and several other comedians. It premiered January 8, 2010 on Comedy Central.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2009/11/comedy-central-gives-john-oliver-his-own-stand-up-comedy-series.html|title=Comedy Central gives John Oliver his own stand-up comedy series|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2009-11-18|accessdate=2009-11-19}}</ref>
In 2009, Oliver made a cameo appearance as the actor [[Rip Torn]] in the music video for [[The Fiery Furnaces]] single "Even in the Rain", which is based around the story of the making of the film ''[[Easy Rider]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/37279-video-premiere-the-fiery-furnaces-even-in-the-rain/|title=Video Premiere:The Fiery Furnaces: "Even in the Rain"|publisher=Pitchfork|date=2009-12-03|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref>
Oliver voiced Vanity Smurf in ''[[The Smurfs (film)|The Smurfs]]'' film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/04/28/smurfs-john-oliver-snl/|title=Smurfs casting update: 'SNL' cast and John Oliver join voice cast|publisher=Entertainment Weekly Online|date=2010-04-28|accessdate=2010-05-03}}</ref>
==Personal life== John Oliver currently lives in [[New York City]] with his wife Kate Norley, an Iraq war veteran.<ref>{{cite news|last=Slonim |first=Jeffrey |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20431492,00.html |title=The Daily Show's John Oliver Is Engaged|work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=2010-10-03 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> Oliver has said that they met at the [[2008 Republican National Convention]] where he was doing a piece for ''The Daily Show'' and Norley was campaigning with [[Vets for Freedom]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://jumbodump.com/2009/06/03/john-oliver-radio-interview-3/ | title= John Oliver Radio Interview| date=2009-06-03| accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref> The two were married in October 2011, according to fellow comic and ''Bugle'' presenter [[Andy Zaltzman]]'s Twitter feed.
Oliver is a fan of [[Liverpool F.C.]]<ref>{{cite web| url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2007/04/john_oliver_fears_the_end_times.html| title='Daily Show' Correspondent John Oliver Fears We're in the End Times| date=2007-04-10| accessdate=2008-04-19}}</ref> and the [[New York Mets]] baseball team.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/us_elections/the_bugle/article6878690.ece| title=The Bugle #93| date=2009-10-16| accessdate=2009-10-17 | location=London | work=The Times | first=Tom | last=Wright}}</ref>
Oliver's status as an immigrant placed certain constraints on what he could do in his adopted country, but also provided him with comedic material as he poked fun at the opacity and occasional absurdity of the process of attaining US citizenship. Oliver was one of the many writers on the picket lines during the [[2007â2008 Writers Guild of America strike|Writer's Guild strike]] which brought ''The Daily Show'' to a halt,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://gothamist.com/2007/11/15/john_oliver_wri.php |title=John Oliver, Writer |date=2007-10-15 |accessdate=2008-04-19}} </ref> but he appeared on the show upon its resuming production on 7 January 2008. During a sketch, he pointed out that he is in the U.S. on a [[Visa (document)|visa]] which requires him not to strike while the show is in production and violation of the terms of the visa would be grounds for deportation. When asked about his immigration status in early 2009, Oliver said, "It's an ongoing, and slightly unsettling, battle to be honest. I tried engraving 'Give me your tired, your poor, and your aspiring comic performers' into the base of the Statue of Liberty, but apparently that's not legally binding."<ref name="Comic Crumpet"/> In an episode of [[The Bugle]] released 31 October 2009, Oliver announced that he "finally got approved for [his] [[Permanent residence (United States)|green card]]," noting that now he can "get arrested filming bits for ''[[The Daily Show]]''".<ref name="Bugle 94">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/us_elections/the_bugle/article6895545.ece|title=The Bugle #94: Does the EU really want El Presidente Blair?|date=31 October 2009|publisher=Times Online|accessdate=2009-10-31 | location=London | first=Tom | last=Wright}}</ref>
Both Oliver's parents are from [[Liverpool, England]].
